channel.title: BBC News - Home
channel.description: The latest stories from the Home section of the BBC News web site.
channel.copyright: Copyright: (C) British Broadcasting Corporation, see http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/help/rss/4498287.stm for terms and conditions of reuse.

item.title: Ban packed lunches, schools urged
item.description: An official review of school food suggests head teachers in England should ban packed lunches and lower the price of cooked dinners to promote healthy eating.

item.title: Snowden 'asks to meet activists'
item.description: Fugitive US intelligence leaker Edward Snowden has requested a meeting with human rights groups at Moscow airport, Russian officials say.

item.title: Ireland backs 'life-saving' abortion
item.description: Lawmakers in the Republic of Ireland vote to allow abortion under certain conditions for the first time, following a marathon debate.

item.title: Cigarette packaging plans on hold
item.description: The government is to postpone plans for standardised plain cigarette packaging, to spend more time studying a similar scheme in Australia.

item.title: Killed soldier's military funeral
item.description: The full military funeral of Fusilier Lee Rigby, who was killed in Woolwich, south-east London, takes place later in Manchester.

item.title: Key Syria rebel 'killed by rival'
item.description: A senior member of the Free Syrian Army is reported to have been killed by a rival rebel group linked to al-Qaeda.

item.title: US warning to Egypt over arrests
item.description: The US warns Egypt against further Muslim Brotherhood arrests, as supporters and opponents of ousted President Morsi prepare for new protests.

item.title: Dementia patients 'miss key tests'
item.description: Many dementia patients fail to have the proper checks when they are in hospital, an audit of care has found.

item.title: Thousands prepare for Orange parades
item.description: Thousands of Orangemen prepare to take part in a total of 550 parades to mark 12 July across Northern Ireland.

item.title: Class divide for boys' reading
item.description: The brightest boys from poor homes in England and Scotland are at least two-and-a-half years behind in reading compared with those from the richest homes, a study suggests

item.title: 'Biggest seizure' of dissident arms
item.description: Irish police say they have made their biggest ever find of dissident republican arms and explosives at a location in north Dublin.

item.title: Brazil row over topless fan ban
item.description: Controversial new plans which include a ban of shirtless and standing fans at Rio de Janeiro's Maracana stadium are causing outcry in Brazil.

item.title: Fangio's F1 Mercedes to be auctioned
item.description: A rare racing car driven by Formula 1 legend Juan Manuel Fangio could fetch more than Â£10m when it goes under the hammer.

item.title: Russia buys typewriters 'over leaks'
item.description: Russia's agency responsible for the Kremlin security is buying typewriters - a move reportedly prompted by recent leaks by WikiLeaks and Edward Snowden.

item.title: England unhappy with Trott dismissal
item.description: England ask for clarification from the ICC after an lbw decision is reversed despite key technology being unavailable.

item.title: Injured Rooney sidelined for a month
item.description: Wayne Rooney is heading home from Manchester United's pre-season tour and will be sidelined for a month with a hamstring problem.

item.title: Ennis-Hill out of GB Championships
item.description: Jessica Ennis-Hill withdraws from this weekend's British Championships in Birmingham because of injury.

item.title: Champions Germany draw Euro opener
item.description: Defending champions Germany draw 0-0 against the Netherlands in their Euro 2013 opening game in Sweden.

item.title: 'Agar? He didn't stand out for Henley CC'
item.description: BBC Sport's chief sports writer Tom Fordyce looks at the remarkable rise of Australia's teenage sensation Ashton Agar

item.title: Co-op 'considered' BoE plan for bank
item.description: Co-op Group considered using the Bank of England's resolution process to deal with its struggling bank, BBC Business Editor Robert Peston has learned.

item.title: US shares surge to record close
item.description: US shares close at record levels following reassurance that efforts to boost the economy by the Federal Reserve will not end soon.

item.title: No need for tax rises, says Osborne
item.description: Chancellor George Osborne says he will not need to raise UK taxes to meet deficit reduction targets after the next election.

item.title: 'Stick' MPs' pay rise, says Gove
item.description: Education Secretary Michael Gove tells Parliament's spending watchdog to "stick" a planned Â£6,000 pay rise for MPs, but officials insist it is fair.

item.title: Gang members prone to mental illness
item.description: Young men in gangs are significantly more likely to suffer from a mental disorder and need psychiatric help than other young men, says a UK study.

item.title: Gene therapy trial 'cures children'
item.description: A disease which robs children of the ability to walk and talk has been cured by pioneering gene therapy to correct errors in their DNA, say doctors.

item.title: New curriculum 'abolishes childhood'
item.description: Young children in England will be required to study mathematical concepts up to two years earlier than their peers in top-performing nations.

item.title: More universities to charge top fees
item.description: Almost three quarters of universities in England are planning to charge the maximum Â£9,000 tuition fee for some or all of their courses, says the Office for Fair Access.

item.title: Nokia reveals 41 megapixel phone
item.description: Nokia's latest handset features a 41 megapixel camera, allowing owners to "shoot first, zoom later" without sacrificing image quality.

item.title: Feds asked to avoid hacker meeting
item.description: Federal agents have been asked to stay away from Def Con - one of the world's biggest hacking and security gatherings.

item.title: Distant quakes linked by waste water
item.description: A study of seismic record shows that earthquakes can be triggered at the sites of wastewater injection by quakes on the other side of the world.

item.title: Glass rain may give planet blue hue
item.description: For the first time, astronomers have determined the true colour of a planet orbiting another star - and it's a deep azure hue.

item.title: Mendes to direct next Bond film
item.description: Skyfall director Sam Mendes is to direct the next James Bond film, due for release in 2015, it is announced.

item.title: Proms to launch with world premiere
item.description: A new work by acclaimed British composer Julian Anderson will open the two-month BBC Proms season later.

item.title: English wine: Is sparkling wine better in England than France?
item.description: The Duchess of Cornwall has called for a new term for English sparkling wine. Is this the final push domestic plonk needs to rival traditional wine nations?

item.title: Carp and coffee: The language of bribes
item.description: The euphemisms used to describe corruption differs from one country to the next, but there are also striking similarities, write David Henig and Nicolette Makovicky.

item.title: Six held over Shard climb protest
item.description: Six Greenpeace protesters who scaled Britain's tallest building are in police custody after being arrested over the demonstration.

item.title: Man in flat arrested by armed police
item.description: A 46-year-old man is arrested after an 11-hour stand-off in a block of flats in Norfolk.

item.title: Arrest over 'fake ecstasy' death
item.description: A 24-year-old man is arrested in connection with the death of a teenage girl who had taken fake ecstasy tablets.

item.title: Salmond sets out independence case
item.description: The Scottish first minister is to argue the country needs independence to stop unpopular policies being "imposed" by the UK government.

item.title: Fire service attends 42 bonfires
item.description: The Northern Ireland Fire and Rescue Service says it dealt with one call every 77 seconds for a period on the Eleventh night.

item.title: Bonfire statue handed in to church
item.description: A religious statue that was placed on a bonfire has been handed in to a Catholic church.

item.title: Internet speed 'hinders' school work
item.description: Slow internet connections at schools are affecting pupils' ICT studies, according to the education watchdog Estyn.

item.title: Dragon Somme memorial to be restored
item.description: A red dragon memorial to Welsh soldiers who died in a World War I battle in northern France is to be restored after the Welsh government pledged Â£7,000.

item.title: SA's Malema launches political group
item.description: South Africa's former ANC youth leader Julius Malema launches a new political group, calling for land redistribution and mine nationalisation.

item.title: Saudi princess 'enslaved' Kenyan
item.description: A woman described as a Saudi princess is arrested in California and accused of human trafficking after a Kenyan woman allegedly escaped from her home.

item.title: Five dead in Indonesia prison break
item.description: Indonesian police search for dozens of inmates who broke out of a Sumatra jail during a riot that left at least five people dead.

item.title: Taiwan braces for Typhoon Soulik
item.description: Taiwan prepares for the arrival of Typhoon Soulik, as schools close and soldiers are placed on stand-by for emergency evacuations.

item.title: Karadzic genocide charge reinstated
item.description: A genocide charge against former Bosnian Serb leader Radovan Karadzic is reinstated at the UN Yugoslav war crimes tribunal at The Hague.

item.title: Steep rise in football transfer fees
item.description: International football transfer numbers fall slightly but the income they generate has risen sharply in the past six months, says governing body Fifa.

item.title: Brazil strikes block ports and roads
item.description: Striking workers block key ports and motorways in Brazil during a nationwide day of protests called by the biggest trade unions.

item.title: US allies demand answers over spying
item.description: US allies Mexico, Brazil, Colombia and Chile join the chorus of disapproval over allegations that the US is conducting widespread espionage.

item.title: Iraq hit by fresh wave of violence
item.description: Bomb and gun attacks across Iraq kill more than 30 people, many of them members of the security forces, in the past day, officials say.

item.title: Syrians 'protest over rebel siege'
item.description: Syrians in Aleppo protest against a rebel siege of government-controlled districts that has created food shortages, residents say.

item.title: Martin's death 'no fault of his own'
item.description: Travyon Martin was shot dead "through no fault of his own" but because George Zimmerman deemed him a criminal, a prosecutor says in closing statements.

item.title: Canada blast missing presumed dead
item.description: Canadian police say 24 bodies have been found since the oil train disaster in Quebec, and another 30 missing people are "most probably dead".

item.title: Your pictures: Lakes
item.description: Readers' photos on the theme of lakes

item.title: Day in pictures: 11 July 2013
item.description: Twenty-four hours of news photos: 11 July

item.title: In pictures: Kashmir train link
item.description: Images of Kashmir's ambitious new train project

item.title: In pictures: Bloodshed in Egypt
item.description: Clashes in Cairo leave dozens dead

item.title: Hampton Court Palace Flower Show
item.description: Famous faces help launch Hampton Court Flower Show

item.title: Day in pictures: 10 July 2013
item.description: Twenty-four hours of news photos: 10 July

item.title: In pictures: Freetown's firefighters
item.description: Fighting Freetown's fires with limited water and just one truck

item.title: In pictures: Pope visits Lampedusa
item.description: Pope Francis visits Italian island of Lampedusa

item.title: VIDEO: House of Lords
item.description: The justice secretary says firms have charged for tagging people who were in jail or had died.

item.title: VIDEO: DNA links 'Boston Strangler' to victim
item.description: US authorities say DNA evidence links a dead convict long suspected to have been a notorious serial killer to a woman murdered nearly 50 years ago.

item.title: VIDEO: Malala to make UN birthday address
item.description: A Pakistani teenager who was shot in the head by the Taliban is to address the United Nations on Friday - on her 16th birthday.

item.title: VIDEO: Rio clashes follow day of strikes
item.description: Police in Rio de Janiero have clashed with demonstrators after a day of strikes across Brazil, called by the country's largest trade unions.

item.title: VIDEO: Mass breakout at Indonesia jail
item.description: At least 150 prisoners have escaped from a jail in the Indonesian city of Medan on the island of Sumatra.

item.title: VIDEO: 'People wonder if I have the capability'
item.description: Myleene Klass has revealed she was concerned people questioned her "capability" to do her job because of her background in a pop band.

item.title: VIDEO: Protesters scale tallest building
item.description: Six protesters from Greenpeace are scaling the highest building in western Europe.

item.title: VIDEO: 'Women prefer mobile gaming'
item.description: Delegates at Brighton's Develop conference for the video game industry, talk about the impact of mobile gaming.

item.title: VIDEO: Cafe targets gulls with water pistols
item.description: Staff at a cafe in the Devon resort of Teignmouth are using water pistols to protect outdoor customers from hungry seagulls.

item.title: How much does a good sea view cost?
item.description: How much would you pay for a view of the beach?

item.title: The armed robber who became a writer
item.description: Who was the mastermind behind the Great Train Robbery?

item.title: The German settlers who left their mark on Palestine
item.description: The Christian settlement doomed by the rise of the Nazis

item.title: 'It's like canoeing in Baghdad'
item.description: Canoeists fight for the 'right to paddle'

item.title: Quiz of the week's news
item.description: What's this odd symbol that has been doing the rounds?

item.title: Lake drama vies for Killing acclaim
item.description: New Zealand's Top of Lake set to grip UK audience

item.title: VIDEO: The family circus aged two to 66
item.description: Three generations perform in circus act - aged 2 to 66

item.title: Papers angry about MPs' pay rise
item.description: Papers angry about MPs' pay rise

item.title: Imaging 'promises pinpoint cancer treatment'
item.description: An expert says cancer care 'could be improved'

item.title: Synthetic biology: A new battleground?
item.description: David Shukman examines the controversy over synthetic biology

item.title: Danny Nightingale: SAS man who will not stop fighting
item.description: SAS man who will not stop fighting
